docs.title: openScope Traveller (OSCA)
docs.text:
A modular, open-source digital microscopy platform for brightfield and fluorescence imaging—portable, field-ready, and designed for rapid setup in teaching or research environments.

Compliance & Purpose - IEEE 1063 Software User Documentation - ISO/IEC 82079‑1 Instructions for use - ISO/IEC 26514 Documentation for end users

Intended audience: technical staff, researchers, trained users.

Key features - Portable (fits two Pelican cases) - Modular optical/illumination design (filter cubes, stackable layers) - Preconfigured software (Micro‑Manager) for fast startup - Brightfield & fluorescence imaging; time‑lapse capable

Start with [[Quickstart →|getting-started/QUICKSTART]].

docs.title: openScopes Connect Africa (OSCA) Traveller
docs.text:
A modular, open-source digital microscopy platform for brightfield and fluorescence imaging—portable, field-ready, and designed for rapid setup in research environments.

The openScope Traveller (or just the Traveller) is a modular, open-source digital microscopy platform designed to provide accessible, field-deployable imaging capabilities for research and teaching. It supports both brightfield and fluorescence imaging modalities, and can be configured for advanced time-lapse acquisitions. The Traveller has been engineered for portability, rapid setup, and reliable operation in both laboratory and field settings.

The Traveller is adapted from the openFrame microscope, a modular and cost-effective platform developed around open-hardware principles. At its core, the openFrame architecture uses stackable cylindrical aluminum layers aligned along a central optical axis. This modular design provides a flexible framework that can accommodate both standard and specialised microscope components. The architecture also makes it straightforward to interface with external optical cage assemblies, offering users an extended range of experimental configurations.

By maintaining compatibility with open-source software tools such as Micro-Manager and ImageJ/Fiji, openFrame-based microscopes remain easy to maintain, simple to upgrade, and adaptable to most light microscopy techniques. This ensures that Traveller users benefit from both hardware modularity and software flexibility.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Portable (fits two Pelican cases)
  • Modular optical/illumination design (filter cubes, stackable layers)
  • Preconfigured software (Micro‑Manager) for fast startup
  • Brightfield & fluorescence imaging; time-lapse capable

See the following pages for more information on the openScopes ecosystem:

  • GitHub openScope Traveller GitHub

  • YouTube openScope Traveller YouTube channel

  • GitHub Pages openScope Traveller GitHub Pages

  • openFrame openFrame GitHub

docs.title: Compliance & Purpose
docs.text:
• IEEE 1063 Software User Documentation
  • ISO/IEC 82079‑1 Instructions for use
  • ISO/IEC 26514 Documentation for end users

Intended audience: microscopy specialists, technical staff, researchers.

docs.title: Acknowledgements
docs.text:
The development of the Traveller was carried out by Fraser Montandon, Jasmin Knopp, and Caron Jacobs. We gratefully acknowledge the support of the Institute of Infectious Disease and Molecular Medicine (IDM) and the Department of Electrical Engineering at the University of Cape Town, and the Wellcome Trust.

We also recognise the broader open-source microscopy and scientific imaging communities, whose contributions continue to inspire accessible and modular imaging solutions. This work builds upon the collaborative spirit exemplified by the openScopes project, conceived by Paul French and colleagues at Imperial College London, which has set a benchmark for open, reproducible, and low-cost scientific instrumentation.

!!! tip "Getting Started" Start with the Quickstart guide to begin using the Traveller.

docs.title: Inventory & Unpacking
docs.text:
1. Open both Pelican cases and inspect components.
  2. Cross‑check contents below; report damage or missing items.

docs.title: Main Assembly
docs.text:
• OF01 openFrame main assembly
  • OF02 Stage & transillumination assembly

docs.title: Transillumination
docs.text:
• OF03 Transillumination source
  • OF18 Transillumination USB cable

docs.title: IRIS‑400 System
docs.text:
• OF04 IRIS‑400 • OF05 dust cover • OF06 ring adaptor • OF07 collimating tube
  • OF08 pedestal • OF22 controller • OF23 power cable • OF19 interlink cable

docs.title: Cameras
docs.text:
• OF11 Rana (colour) • OF12 dust cover • OF15 USB
  • OF09 Kikker (mono) • OF10 dust cover • OF16 USB • OF20 Power

docs.title: Connectivity
docs.text: • OF17 USB Hub

docs.title: Stage, Objectives & Accessories
docs.text:
• OF21 Slide holder • OF29 Stage cover • OF30 Test slides
  • Objectives: OF23 10×/0.25, OF24 20×/0.40, OF25 40×/0.65, OF26 100× oil/1.25
  • OF31 Texas Red filter cube (additional to multiband cube)

docs.title: Laptop
docs.text: • OF27 Dell Rugged Laptop • OF28 Charger

docs.title: ScopeView
docs.text: • OF32 Gooseneck • OF33 Camera

docs.title: Tools
docs.text: • T01 PH1 screwdriver • T02 2.0 mm hex • T03 2.5 mm hex • T04 3.0 mm hex

docs.title: Kit Overview
docs.text: Two Pelican cases: - Case A (Mechanical & Cameras): OF01 base, OF02 stage & pillar, camera case. - Case B (Electronics & Illumination): IRIS‑400N, lenses, toolkit, power, cables, preconfigured laptop.

docs.title: Quickstart
docs.text:
This manual covers the Traveller’s assembly, software setup, operation, and maintenance. While the Traveller represents a compact implementation of the openFrame ecosystem, users should note that the framework supports larger and more elaborate designs. These extended systems can include additional imaging modalities and integrations for core imaging facilities. Although beyond the scope of this manual, such expansions remain available for advanced users and institutions seeking enhanced capabilities.

The full assembly guide and user manual is available here: See the Assembly Guide for detailed steps.

  1. Place OF01 openFrame on a stable, low‑vibration surface (≥110×80 cm). Do not move after assembly.
  2. Mount OF02 Stage & Transillumination: align arrows →1/→2; tighten S02/S03 using 2.5 mm hex (T03).
  3. Attach OF03 Transillumination: USB toward pillar; seat onto posts; tighten the two top screws using 2.5 mm hex (T03).
  4. Install cameras: OF09 Kikker (mono) and OF11 Rana (color) with labels up; hand‑tighten (do not over tighten).
  5. Fit OF04 IRIS‑400: add OF06 ring adaptor (three grub screws 2.0 mm hex (T02)), insert OF07 tube to the guideline, support body on OF08 pedestal ~20 cm left of IRIS port.
  6. Cable up:
  7. IRIS: OF22 controller OUTPUT ⇄ OF04 via OF19; power via OF23 (arrows up).
  8. Cameras: OF16 USB + OF20 12V → Kikker; OF15 USB → Rana.
  9. Hub: OF17 → Laptop (P01).
  10. Transillumination: OF18 USB‑C → Laptop (P02).
  11. Remove transport screws on multiband cube and mirror slider using 3.0 mm hex (T04); store safely.
  12. Power laptop; login. Launch Micro‑Manager, choose Default User, config: CellCam MultimodeLED.cfg.
  13. Brightfield: filter to Empty, Channel → Mid RGB, Live, exposure 1–50 ms typical.
  14. Fluorescence: filter to Multiband, camera Kikker, IRIS R/G/B/UV LED, Live, exposure 100–800 ms typical.

docs.title: Safety & Handling
docs.text:
• Electrical: Use grounded outlets and supplied power adapters; disconnect power before modifications.
  • Optical: Avoid direct viewing of LEDs; use eye protection for high-intensity/UV.
  • Mechanical: Secure the base on a stable table; handle rails and mounts carefully.
  • Transport: Use supplied Pelican cases; avoid stacking weight on cases.
  • Tools: Use only supplied tools:
    • Phillips screwdriver (size PH1) #T01
    • Hex key driver 2.0mm #T02
    • Hex key driver 2.5mm #T03
    • Hex key driver 3.0mm #T04

docs.title: Assembly Guide
docs.text:
The complete assembly guide is available in the manual. See the Manual for detailed steps. Below is condensed version to get familiar with the Traveller.

Allocate ~2 hours. Wear gloves; protect optics.

docs.title: Step 0 — Toolkit
docs.text: Use only the supplied tools: Phillips PH1 (T01), 2.0 mm hex (T02), 2.5 mm hex (T03), 3.0 mm hex(T04)). Use tools only where explicitly instructed.

docs.title: Step 1 — Foundational openFrame (OF01)
docs.text:
• Place OF01 on a sturdy table (≥110×80 cm), in a low‑vibration, low‑dust, low‑ambient‑light room.
  • Remove baffles C4 and C5 if present.

    Warning: Once assembled, do not move the openFrame.

docs.title: Step 2 — Stage & Transillumination (OF02)
docs.text:
1. Loosen S02/S03 on OF01 using 2.5 mm hex (T03). Do not remove completely.
  2. Align arrow labels (→1 with →1; →2 with →2) on OF01 and the underside of OF02. Seat onto dowel pins until you feel a click and the stage sits level.
  3. Tighten S02/S03 using 2.5 mm hex (T03).
  4. Adjust pillar height using the transillumination height screw as needed.

docs.title: Step 3 — Transillumination Source (OF03)
docs.text:
1. Loosen the two top screws on OF03 using 2.5 mm hex (T03); keep them in place.
  2. Orient USB connector toward the pillar.
  3. Press OF03 onto the mounting posts on OF02; avoid pressing LEDs directly.
  4. Apply even pressure along the perimeter and tighten screws using 2.5 mm hex (T03)**.

docs.title: Step 4 — Cameras (Kikker & Rana)
docs.text:
• Kikker (OF09): remove OF10 dust cover; thread onto Kikker port, label up; hand‑tighten only.
  • Rana (OF11): remove OF12 dust cover; thread onto Rana port, label up; hand‑tighten only.

docs.title: Step 5 — IRIS‑400 Fluorescence (OF04)
docs.text:
1. Place OF08 pedestal ~20 cm left of IRIS port on OF01.
  2. Fit OF06 ring adaptor into OF04 and secure with three grub screws using 2.0 mm hex (T02).
  3. Insert OF07 tube into the IRIS port on OF01 up to the guideline (do not exceed).
  4. Support the OF04 body on OF08; rotate pedestal to adjust height until it gently supports IRIS‑400.

docs.title: Step 6 — Power & Data Cabling
docs.text:
1. IRIS: connect OF22 OUTPUT → OF04 with OF19. Power OF22 via OF23 (align arrows up; keyed connector—do not force).
  2. Rana: OF15 USB → OF11 and hub OF17.
  3. Kikker: OF16 USB → OF09 and hub OF17; connect OF20 12 V DC to OF09.
  4. Hub: OF17 → Laptop port P01.
  5. Transillumination: OF18 USB‑C → Laptop port P02.
  6. Place OF21 slide holder on stage (magnetic).
  7. Remove two transport screws on multiband cube (both sides) and two on mirror slider using 3.0 mm hex (T04). Store safely.

docs.title: Step 7 — Finalise
docs.text:
• Connect laptop power OF28; power Kikker and IRIS.
  • Install only required objectives in the turret; rotate turret manually.
  • Proceed to the Software Guide.

docs.title: Cabling & Power
docs.text:
• Maintain strain relief and gentle bends on all cables.
  • IRIS controller INPUT uses a keyed connector—align arrows up and do not force.
  • Kikker requires both USB and 12 V DC.
  • Use the supplied USB hub (OF17) for stable bandwidth.

docs.title: IRIS‑400 Setup & Operation
docs.text:
• Power on OF22 controller.
  • Select wavelength R/G/B/UV with front buttons. A red dot indicates the selected channel.
  • Turn the right‑side dial to set intensity for the selected LED.
  • Press the button below the LED indicator to toggle illumination ON.

Good practice - Start with longer wavelengths (R/G) and low intensity; increase gradually to minimize photodamage and thermal drift.

docs.title: Objectives & Stage
docs.text:
• Start with low magnification (e.g., 10×) to find the specimen; then step up.
  • Use immersion oil only with 100× oil (OF26).
  • X/Y micrometers move laterally; Z focus adjusts the focal plane. Avoid objective–coverslip contact.

docs.title: Data Management
docs.text:
• Save acquisitions to D:/ (temporary). Create a folder per user/institution.
  • Do not save to C:/ (reserved for OS and imaging software backend).
  • D:/ is purged periodically; copy data to external USB or institutional cloud at session end.
  • Verify integrity by reopening a subset before deleting from D:/.

Formats & Naming - TIFF (8‑ or 12‑bit), AVI for time‑lapse. - Example naming: YYYYMMDD_SampleID_UserInitials_Mode.tif (e.g., 20250620_EColi_FM_BF.tif) - TIFF headers embed metadata (exposure, illumination, objective, notes) when supported.

Security & Backup - Keep at least two independent copies (local+external, or local+cloud). - Encrypt sensitive/unpublished data if required by policy. - Follow your institution’s data retention/sharing rules.

docs.title: Disassembly & Storage
docs.text:
• Follow the reverse order of the Assembly Guide.
  • Pack hardware into the supplied Pelican cases in their cutouts.
  • Store in a cool, dry environment.

docs.title: Optical
docs.text:
• Wear powder‑free gloves when handling optics.
  • Use a bulb blower to remove visible dust on objectives only when artefacts are seen.
  • Do not touch optical surfaces unless instructed by support.

docs.title: Software
docs.text: • Check GitHub monthly for updates.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Issue Likely Cause Resolution Micro-Manager start-up error USB devices disconnect or incorrectly connected Check USB device assignment; restart Micro‑Manager Image too dark or too bright Exposure time adjustment Check histogram and adjust exposure time as required Image too dark LED not powered Check LED connections and power Poor resolution Smudged/misaligned lens Clean objective with blower; refocus

docs.title: CAD & Related Repositories
docs.text:
• OSCA (this project): https://github.com/frasermo/OSCA
  • openFrame reference designs & CAD: https://github.com/ImperialCollegeLondon/openFrame

Sample images and videos can be added under /images and linked from relevant pages.

docs.title: Revision History
docs.text: Version Date Changes Authors 0.1 2025-07-01 Initial release Montandon, Knopp, Jacobs

docs.title: Technical Specifications
docs.text:
• Total weight (system): ~40 kg
  • Architecture: modular openFrame with stackable cylindrical layers
  • Modalities: brightfield & fluorescence; time‑lapse capable

docs.title: Fluorophore Excitation Reference
docs.text:
Multiband filter (DAPI/Green/Orange) — example bandpasses - Excitation: 375±28 nm, 475±40 nm, 560±35 nm - Emission: example band at 625±40 nm (Texas Red)

Texas Red filter set — separate cube with matched excitation/dichroic/emission.

Always verify your fluorophore spectra vs LED wavelengths and filter sets when planning experiments.

docs.title: Histograms 101 (Image Intensity)
docs.text:
• A histogram shows the distribution of pixel intensities (X = intensity; Y = count).
  • Wide distributions imply higher contrast; narrow imply lower contrast.
  • Avoid clipping at the minimum (0) or maximum (e.g., 4095 for 12‑bit) to preserve detail.

Display Min/Max in Micro‑Manager - In Live view, adjust the histogram sliders to change display range (does not alter underlying pixel values). - Ensure the curve fits within your min/max to avoid hiding real pixels.

docs.title: Brightfield Imaging Workflow
docs.text:
1. Insert an objective; in Micro‑Manager, select the matching Objective (update each time you change objectives to keep metadata correct).
  2. Set filter layer to Empty (pull slider to the position labeled Empty).
  3. Place the slide (coverslip down). Enable Auto Shutter.
  4. Choose camera: Kikker (monochrome; default) or Rana (color for histology, etc.).
  5. Set mirror slider: left for color (Rana), right for mono (Kikker).
  6. Channel → Mid RGB; click Live to open Preview and Histogram windows.
  7. Adjust exposure to spread the histogram without clipping (typ. 1–50 ms). If the histogram is left‑skewed (dark), increase exposure; if right‑skewed (overexposed), decrease.
  8. Focus with X/Y micrometers and Z focus. Avoid contacting the slide.
  9. Confirm dynamic range: in 12‑bit mono, avoid pixels at 4095 (saturation). Adjust exposure or LED intensity accordingly.
  10. Save: click Save in the Preview window, or Stop Live → Snap → Save.

docs.title: Fluorescence Imaging Workflow
docs.text:
1. Insert objective; select matching Objective in Micro‑Manager (keep metadata accurate).
  2. Set filter layer to Multiband (DAPI/FITC/TRITC).
  3. Place the slide and cover with the stage cover to reduce ambient light.
  4. Select Kikker camera; Auto Shutter on; set mirror slider right (to Kikker).
  5. In Channels, set OFF initially; click Live.
  6. On IRIS‑400, select R/G/B/UV wavelength; adjust intensity; press the button to turn ON.
  7. Increase exposure until visible (100–800 ms typical). Start with longer wavelengths to reduce photodamage.
  8. Focus; refine exposure to maximize contrast without clipping. In 12‑bit mono, avoid maxed pixels at 4095.
  9. Save via Save or Stop Live → Snap → Save.

docs.title: ScopeView (Auxiliary)
docs.text: Mount OF32 gooseneck and OF33 camera to the Traveller if you need operator‑view video support. Connect OF33 to the USB hub of the laptop. Start up the laptop, login, and double-click on the Scopeview icon on the desktop. (This page will be expanded in time.)

docs.title: Software Guide (Micro‑Manager)
docs.text:
1. Ensure connections: OF17→P01, OF18→P02.
  2. Power laptop; login using the supplied Username and Password.
  3. Launch Micro‑Manager.
  4. In the startup window, select Default User profile and config CellCam MultimodeLED.cfg.
  5. Continue with [[Brightfield|BRIGHTFIELD]] or [[Fluorescence|FLUORESCENCE]].
